title: Rusia Se Promovează Ca Un Paradis Pentru „conservatorii Occidentali” și Le Cere Să Migreze. Câte Persoane Au Răspuns Apelului
cleaned_sentences: Contents: The initiative comes in the context in which the Kremlin promotes conservative values ​​and is positioned in opposition to the Western liberal agenda.

Presidential decree to facilitate immigration In April, President Putin signed a decree that simplifies the process of obtaining the residence for Westerners who share the "traditional Russian spiritual and moral values".
Butina explained to The Moscow Times: "This means people who do not support LGBT movements, people who believe that their children should be raised traditionally."

Statistics on immigration in Russia According to data provided by the Butinai Bureau, 4,676 Westerners requested temporary asylum in Russia in 2022, and 2,358 requested a temporary residence permit in 2023.
Over 200 people have moved to Russia since the signing of the Decree in April.
Most come from Germany and the Baltic states, with 1,237 and 1,802 immigrants respectively.

Expert criticisms Sam Greene, the director of the Russian Institute at King's College London, believes that Kremlin's efforts are rather an opportunity for PR than a real attempt to attract Westerners.
"I do not think that the Kremlin is actually interested in bringing many Westerners to live in Russia, but rather seek opportunities for PR wins," he told The Moscow Times.
The exodus of Russia and the repression Despite the efforts to attract immigrants, Russia is facing a massive exodus of their own citizens and foreigners of 2022.
The Bell's publication estimates that about 650,000 people have permanently left the country since the beginning of the war.
Many have invoked the fear of war, mobilization and political repression.
Foreigners were not immune to Russia's repression during war.
There were reports about the long border interrogators for the citizens of the countries that the Kremlin considers "unfriendly".
American journalists Evan Gershkovich and Alsu Kurmasheva spent long periods in prison before being released into a major exchange of prisoners with the West in August.
Despite these cases, Butina insists that those who want to move have no concern: "If you come here legally, do not break any law, then you will be good, I can guarantee you."
